This is the definition of a Labour of Love! Development started in 2002, it was first publicly released in 2006, and it remains actively developed, with no end in sight.

Generate vast, procedurally created worlds complete with detailed histories, civilizations, and ecosystems, then manage a group of dwarves to construct and defend an underground fortress against threats like sieges, monsters, and environmental hazards

Dwarf Fortress emphasises complex simulation mechanics, including individual dwarf personalities, skills, needs, and interactions that can lead to emergent storytelling and challenges!

I have been playing Dwarf Fortress since 2017, and through that time spend many thousands of hours before the steam release, and I'm sure I will continue to play it for many thousands more. It is the most detailed, immersive colony-sim / story generator that exists.

Dwarf Fortress is self-directed and self-motivated; it's not the sort of game you can ever beat.

There's a pretty steep learning curve -- exponentially less now with the 50.+ release and GUI / mouse interface and tutorials -- but learning how to get a fortress to produce soap, steel, dyed and studded clothes, instruments, books, all take understanding and organization and time.

The fact that Tarn continues to push out substantial updates that rework or implement entirely new systems is ongoing testament to his life-long dedication to the project and the consistency of his vision and roadmap into the future.

May Amok guide your pick! STRIKE THE EARTH!

After numerous fortresses that got off to a peaceful start, I knew it was time for a greater challenge. I had never experienced a haunted location before and had been warned to not embark upon one but my interest was piqued. 

I found a nice haunted place surrounded by goblin pits and decided this would give me action a bit more quickly than usual. I spent ages kitting out the dwarves to make sure I had the perfect party to embark and be prepared for anything that could possibly come at them. 

Looking around the landscape, everything looked so much weirder than I was accustomed to; plants I had never heard of and the ground was covered in slime. 

As soon as I unpaused, a zombie ogre seemed to appear out of nowhere and grab the first dwarf by the arm, tearing it off in one swift motion. The unarmed dwarf started running away and the ogre was in pursuit. Meanwhile the arm that had been cast away suddenly re-animated and grabbed another dwarf by the throat. It squeezed hard until that dwarf was decapitated but then the head also got re-animated and bit another dwarf in the foot, tearing the toes off. 

Within moments, every single dwarf had lost limbs which were all re-animated and crawling around attacking each other. 

Then the sky opened and blood started to rain upon the landscape...
Great game, infinite possibilities, insane dwarves. Please play this game.

Dwarf Fortress — A God-Tier Strategy Game That Somehow Got Snubbed

Dwarf Fortress not getting a Game Awards nomination for Strategy/Simulation 2025 is a joke. The nominees this year were forgettable at best, embarrassing at worst. Meanwhile, this game exists — a world simulator so deep it might as well be an alternate universe running on your hard drive.

Two guys built this. Two.
And their work absolutely deserves recognition.

In Dwarf Fortress you can build religions from scratch, carve entire civilizations out of a mountainside, pump magma through engineered reservoirs to vaporize invaders, raise the dead, imprison demons, create legendary taverns, collapse entire caverns by accident, and lose your fortress in 300 different hilarious and catastrophic ways. You will fail over and over — and you’ll love every second of it.

Not in depth.

Your imagination is the actual limit here. If you can dream it, the game will let you attempt it — and probably punish you for it in some spectacular fashion.

I've been in these mines for years, longer than even I could tell you. I remember hearing whispers of a game called Slaves of ARMOK in school, but while searching around the old internet, found Dwarf Fortress instead. When the Steam listing popped up, I was so excited. This is a game of truly endless entertainment, but you need to work for it, and it will be unforgiving. Literally my first game in this version I had a dwarf, the only one with an axe, either get carried up a tree by a bird, or climbed up the tree to eat the bird's eggs and got stuck. Either way, he refused to climb back down because he was so offended that the bird existed, and died up there. The rest of my dwarves got so depressed because they could see his corpse in the tree, they all stopped working and only drank until dying. Minecraft's ancestor, this fantasy world simulator is extremely old and complex but somewhat easy, meaning you can have fun without understanding most of what's going on. You can try the game for free on the bay12games website, but you'll have to either tolerate ASCII graphics or mod in a tileset nowhere near as good as what you get with the Steam version, which also adds music and sounds.

Fortress mode, the mode where you build a colony in the world, is fleshed out and I prefer it over Rimworld. Dwarves are resilient and hardworking giving lots of room for neglect in the early game, where I tend to worry more about accidentally flooding my fortress. You can send units to interract with other civilizations or be visited by them in the form of traders and raiders, some might even join your fortress.

Adventure mode, the mode where you create and play as one or multiple units in open world roguelike fashion, is a concept I actually prefer. Unfortunately, it still feels barebones as you can't build or dig (But you can join one of your fortresses from fortress mode) and many skills go unused. On the upside, turn-based combat describing your foe being decapitated down to the bruised organs is surprisingly satisfying.

After 10h of gameplay, I can tell confidently that I HATED my time playing this game, mostly because of one main thing that plagues every aspect and square inch of this game: a truly impressively bad user interface (UI) and user experience (UX).
Here, I'm talking menus, their layouts, the unintuitive, slow and convoluted way you need to click at things all the time, the way elements to craft/build/do are displayed, arranged, ordered, grouped, etc. I've never seen anything so bad in my entire life.
I never thought that I could be traumatized by a bad game UI and design, but here we are.

This game was launched originally in 2006, not in 1988. There was good UIs back then, so the fact that the game is old is not even a good excuse. SimCity 4 came out in 2003. And even if the game is old, a UI can change, can evolve, can be refined, refactored. Nothing of this sort here after 20+ years of development. Just a bad UI experience which was never cared for, and which will probably never be fixed. Once again, impressively bad.

This game can be overwhelmingly detailed about things that you really don't care, like every body part down to the teeth having a health status, while at the same time, the game doesn't care to explain to you the basics of how this or that object is produced, or what it can be used for. "You just need to go read the Wiki!" players often respond. Yeah that's right, to make up for a really badly designed game, I now need to go read 50 pages of wiki just to try to understand what the hell the game developer tried to do on this specific feature. This is madness. This is not how games are supposed to work. This is not a scientific simulation software, this is sold on Steam, this is just a game. A BAD GAME.

Sometimes, things are even outright misleading, with the same object being referenced by two different names in different UI panels. For example, I discovered at some point, enraged, that the names "chair" and "throne" were referencing the same object (I tried to find where I could craft a "throne' by searching for 10 minutes in every workshop possible...), and a bit later discovered that "mug" and "goblet" were also the same object. Wonderful. In a game where you can craft hundreds (thousands?) of different objects, I'm not so sure things like this exist because of a huge lack of care or outright evil. 

If the game was embodied into human form, they would be overly obsessed about useless details in obscure subjects, while at the same time being completely socially indifferent, not looking you in the eyes, not speaking nicely to you, not caring about how you feel, and just ignoring you in general. This is what Dwarf Fortress felt like to me. If you try to play the game for the first time, and even after playing the tutorial (at least, there was an attempt), you will notice that the game itself, its entire structure, doesn't care about you. It doesn't even try to have a somewhat modern or standard way for you to play a game. This is truly appalling. I got very angry at some point because of the obvious lack of empathy towards the players displayed by the game itself.

Ironically enough, the main slogan of the game is "Losing is Fun". Before I started to play, I imagined that the meaning of this was about a high difficulty, Dark Souls-like. I imagined that creatures would attack my base if I forgot to build defenses, things like this. And i guess that a lot of players probably see this slogan this way. But oh, no, that's not how I see it now.
Instead, this slogan resonates in me with this meaning now: "You see, the game is so badly designed, every mechanic and UI element is so cryptic and difficult to understand that you have no idea what you're supposed to do or what the game is doing, therefore, you will lose a lot. But look! This is so fun right!!!!"
No, this is not fun. This is a delusional post-rationalization of a bad game, created purely to support a lack of accountability when it comes to fixing it. To every problem that the game has, one can answer "Losing is fun!".

This slogan is to me the illustration of how delusional people can get about their own work or habits they developed. "What i made is bad? No no, you don't get it, this is intentional! Yeah, actually this is intentionally bad haha! You see? Problem solved!"

This slogan has become ironic to me when I see it anywhere.

The game is also bad is a very weird way. The game is not lazy in the traditional sense of "lack of features", there is a LOT of features and things going on in Dwarf Fortress. But this is exactly the problem. Too much is going on, without any explanation, without anything being put in order. It's like this game has Diogenes syndrome: 
- severe self-neglect (of the UI)
- domestic squalor (of the menus)
- social withdrawal (doesn't care about the players)
- compulsive hoarding (thousands of objets, lore elements, personality traits, body part health statuses, mechanics, etc)
- lack of shame (no care for fixing the base aspects of the game after 20 years of development, while still adding new features).
Yep, actually, everything in this game checks out this definition pretty well.

But why waste my time with this game then if I hate it so much? Why did I take the time to write such a long review today?
Well, because I feel like something wrong happened to me here. I was really ready to love this game. There is a big community of players around this game, and they really made me think that this game was a truly good game. I trusted them, and I just feel betrayed now. I feel wronged. I lost my time, and the only thing I got from this game is hours of frustration instead of entertainment. I need to balance this out. When games do something wrong, they need to be called out for it. That's what happened with Starfield, with Cyperpunk 2077, etc. Here, it's a little bit different because this is an indie game. I really feel like this game has been too bad for too long to be excusable.
